text_title: Fawz al-muslimīn fī ḥubb al-khulafā’ al-rāshidīn
author_biography: 1938-2006. A son of Malam Danganagi (q.v.), his mother Ḥalīma was the daughter of Wazirin Bida Muḥammad (q.v.). He was born in Owo (Ile-Ife), but grew up in Bida. He began his studies with Yaḥyā b. ‘Īsā and Sani Makwalla amongst others. When the first Islamiyya school opened in Bida in 1953 (under the patronage of ‘Abd al-Qādr b. ‘Alī, q.v.), he enrolled there and studied under ‘Alī Gusau and Idrīs b. Muḥammad Ɗandume (q.v.). Then he went to Kano for further formal studies at the School of Arabic Studies, as well as informal studies in the circle of Ismā‘īl Sagagi. He taught at an Islamiyya school in Bida, and animated a private study circle in his house
notes: Biographies of the four first caliphs, drawn from al-Suyūṭī’s al-Khulafā’ al-rāshidūn

text_title: Marthiyyat al-shaykh Ibrāhīm
author_biography: Born in Ɗandume (today’s Katsina State), he began his studies with Muḥammad al-Awwal Ɗandume, before traveling to Zaria to pursue further studies with ‘Abd al-Qādir b. ‘Alī (q.v.), whom he also accompanied on a trip to Kaolack. In the following years, ‘Abd al-Qādir b. ‘Alī was asked by the Nupe Maɗaki (a traditional aristocratic title) of Bida to send some scholars to Nupeland to improve Islamic literacy and promote the Tijāniyya. The first two scholars sent by ‘Abd al-Qādir (‘Alī Tsafe and ‘Alī Tsakiya) did not settle well in Bida. Idrīs Ɗandume, on the contrary, settled and spent fifty-five years of his life there, teaching, writing and initiating many in the Tijāniyya across Nupeland and the Middle Belt. Among his muqaddam-s are Muḥammad, imam of Saganuwa; Muḥammad, imam of Sosa; Shehu Ƙofar Agaie; Ḥayātu Bakin Kasuwa Bida; Muḥammad al-Thānī Lalemi; Liman Yamma Sharu of Kacha; Yūsuf Iyaruwa; Abū Bakr Agaie; Muḥammad Mai Tafsiri Agaie; etc. He wrote many poems, especially eulogies.
